pageContext.claim: “We’re ending the chain migration where, in his case, they say he might have had up to 24 people come in with him, indirectly — aunts, uncles, cousins, grandfathers, grandmothers.”
pageContext.analysis: This is an exaggeration. In September 2017, the Center for Immigration Studies released a one pager on chain migration. The report found that ""According to the most complete contemporary academic studies on chain migration, in recent years each new immigrant sponsored an average of 3.45 additional immigrants. In the early 1980s, the chain migration multiplier was 2.59, or more than 30 percent lower."" In most cases the sponsored family members were spouses and parents -- not distant relatives.
